Description: Fragmentary rim of a massive basin, more specifically sha-basin, carved in black basalt; two rows of incised hieroglyphic text on the exterior surface; polished surface, bit chipped and damaged.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (probably)
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sais, According to Petrie diary (possibly)
Curator's comments: Sha-basins are ritual basins (Wörterbuch der ägyptischen Sprache vol. IV, 1971, 401, 2) particularly typical of the Ptolemaic period (Yoyotte 1994-95, 674). This basin was not discovered in the Great Temenos at Naukratis though this is what Griffith has stated (in Gardner 1888, 81). This find is mentioned in Petrie journal 1884-1885: aside a sketch with the hieroglyphic inscription, it is written '(bought for 1 franc, perhaps from Sais)'. On this sha-basin, see: Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVI, 3; Gardner 1888, 81, pl. XXIII, 3; Yoyotte 1994-95, 674 (with wrong ref. to Gardner 1888). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Yoyotte, J. 1994/95, ‘Les contacts entre Égyptiens et Grecs (viie-iie siècles avant J.-C.) : Naucratis, ville égyptienne’, Annuaire du Collège de France, 669-82.
